data.title: All Jamaicans through as Team USA (not Lyles) posts fastest time in men’s 100m heats
data.meta_description: Team Jamaica's medal prospects increased with all three athletes advancing to the semi-final rounds at the 2024 Paris Olympic Games on Saturday (August 3). Progressing nonetheless, self-proclaimed 'fastest' Noah Lyles was the only losing American sprinter in the first round of the men's 100-metre dash as Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley jointly posted 9.97 seconds
data.text:
Reading Time: 2 minutes

Team Jamaica’s medal prospects increased with all three athletes advancing to the semi-final rounds at the 2024 Paris Olympic Games on Saturday (August 3).

Progressing nonetheless, self-proclaimed ‘fastest’ Noah Lyles was the only losing American sprinter in the first round of the men’s 100-metre dash as Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley jointly posted 9.97 seconds to hold the quickest time heading into the next round.

In a balmy Stade de France, Kishane Thompson, the world’s fastest man this year, cinched Heat 1 in 10.00 seconds ahead of Ghana’s Benjamin Azamati (10.08s) and Reynaldo Espinosa of Cuba (10.11s).

Kenya’s Ferdinand Omanyala took Heat 2 with a sporty 10.08s, ahead of Italian Chituru Ali (10.12s) and Joshua Hartmann from Germany (10.16s).

Lyles (10.04s), who finished second in Heat 3 behind British collegiate athlete Louie Hinchcliffe (9.98s), secured his automatic qualification spot ahead of South Africa’s Shaun Maswanganyi (10.06s).

Jamaican Oblique Seville dominated Heat 4 to win in 9.99s, crossing the finish line in front of Abdul Hakim Sani Brown from Japan (10.02s) and Thailand’s Puripol Boonson (10.13s).

Nigerian national champion Kayinsola Ajayi upset defending Olympic title holder Lamont Marcel Jacobs—stopping the clock in 10.02s ahead of the Italian (10.05s) and Ghana’s Abdul-Rasheed Saminu (10.06s) in Heat 5.

Prolific South African sprinter Akani Simbine took Heat 6 in 10.03s to best Jamaica’s Ackeem Blake (10.06s) and Rikkoi Brathwaite from the British Virgin Islands (10.13s).

Bednarek was in a no-nonsense mood in Heat 7, taking the tape 9.97s ahead of Cameroon’s Emmanuel Eseme (9.98s) and Canadian ace Andre de Grasse (10.07s).

Kerley then replicated his compatriot’s time in the final heat, finishing ahead of Botswanan Letsile Tebogo (10.01s) and Britain’s Zharnel Hughes (10.03s).

The semi-finals kick off at 1:05 pm Jamaica time on August 4.
